posts.name: Ray Flanagan
posts.cooked:
Looking for some ideas to handle collaboration with larger programming teams.

Live share?

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked: Pair programming is great for large teams especially when you’re dealing with differences in experience & ability. 1 strong programmer & 1 more inexperienced programmers is a great mentor/mentee pairing where the experience can get passed to the other student. 2 inexperienced students also pair well as they can help each other out and build off of their collective knowledge.

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
FloppyDks:

Live share?

Of course not!

First of all, everyone’s job should be clear and you should share the tasks. It’s not like everyone will make robots. Some develop the necessary applications, some do image processing, some run social responsibility projects, some make games. It would be nice if you could follow them on one application.

The most important thing here is git . git allows programmers to work on the same codebase at the same time and allows version control. Git is just a version control tool. In other words, you need to keep the code on a server to share it. Github is usually used for this, but there are other alternatives. So basically, all software developers should know git and github . Not only FRC , all programming teams use it.

There are some best practices when using Git. If you pay attention to these, your codebase will be much more manageable and easy to track.

posts.name: Ray Flanagan
posts.cooked: Why not live share?

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: It’s a mess

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Live share can be useful as an alternative to screen sharing, but imo it’s not really a good way to code together.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
Learn to use GitHub effectively. Make sure every project is being worked on in a different branch, and try to avoid having two people working out of the same branch at the same time.

It’s better to spend time resolving merge conflicts than debugging code changes you didn’t know someone else made.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: git

Having git version control has saved me multiple times at comp and I fully recommend to every team, even team’s with only one programmer (my use case).

Being able to roll back one commit or checkout the main branch and have code that is confirmed to work has saved me from having to tell my team we won’t move in our next match. It is such a powerful tool and I could never go without.

use github!!

rather than live share i think it’s better to parcel out various tasks that can be worked on in parallel- things like individual mechanisms and projects like vision, autoaim, etc. this helps people stay much more engaged and, importantly, gives them a sense of ownership and pride they can take in their project.

pair programming with an experienced/inexperienced student is also great. there’s usually enough stuff on a robot that can be divvied up for various experience levels

Honestly, just using something like github and an app like notion or even just a whiteboard will take you far. We were in version hell in which we have like 30 versions of code with the same names because we keep on doing minor tweaks and making  new folders. Just try to schedule programming meetings and organize your git.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Doing code review is also incredibly valuable, I can’t emphasize it enough. It’s a quick way to glance over what changes have been made before they get merged into main, but it means that everyone can keep up to date on what the codebase looks like. If it’s possible to do a code review with the full programming team before merging anything into main, I highly recommend it.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
I’ll also back Git. You don’t need to be an expert it in (it’s a very deep rabbit hole), but the 95% use case is like 4 commands and a handful of relatively straightforward concepts. Committing, branching, switching, and merging basically sum it up. Merging tends to be the trickiest one initially. Have your most capable student (or mentor) take the lead to walk through how to resolve those, since I’ve found most students completely panic the first time they run into it, often with very undesirable results.

Since you’re probably in VS Code, this is my favorite plugin to help visualize a project with multiple students working on it. No network requirements, so it’s a lifesaver at competitions. https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=mhutchie.git-graph

The other aspect is just task management . This is an annual pain point for us, but trying to keep tabs on all the little things that need to get done winds up building a lot of involvement. There’s usually little side tasks and cleanup that can pull in some effort.

Lastly, don’t expect all members of a large programming team to be working on the bot at all times. Often times, once the bot is coded up and working, the additional feature sets can fall off quickly, leaving only minor tuning and update tasks, and a requirement to test it on the physical bot. In these cases, having a backlog of off-robot projects, test benches, or simulation tooling can help a lot. IMO, the hard part here is convincing the students that this work is providing value to the team, which tends to be critical to the buy-in process.

tekdemo:

I’ll also back Git. You don’t need to be an expert it in (it’s a very deep rabbit hole), but the 95% use case is like 4 commands and a handful of relatively straightforward concepts.

…

If that doesn't fix it, git.txt contains the phone number of a friend of mine who understands git. Just wait through a few minutes of 'It's really pretty simple, just think of branches as...' and eventually you'll learn the commands that will fix everything.

But yes 100% recommend Git.

Also in relation to git, if you find yourself having to do something to fix a mistake such as committing to the wrong branch, here’s a good (and funny) reference for commands to get you out of those binds: https://dangitgit.com/

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked:
Everyone is recommending Git…

Are there teams that don’t use Git???

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: make use of pull requests, and issues tracking in github. generally have programming members in general groups to go to during meetings. atleast for my team, less experienced members get simpler tasks that take them longer so they can still contribute, while more experienced members do the bulk of the more complex code, and tuning

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Teams that don’t use git probably don’t have a CD presence.
you’d be surprised

posts.name: Doug Kavner
posts.cooked:
Andrew123ast:

Are there teams that don’t use Git???

Just the teams that only have a robotInit() and do everything else themselves with no WPILib calls. We once picked such a team without knowing it and it turned out that their lone programmer wasn’t even at the event.

Seriously, if you want help from others, use standard tools and techniques, including git. The power of being able to pull up a git diff to show someone what you changed will pay you back 100x. Once you see what you can do with extensions like Git Graph and Git Blame, you will never go back.
